chapter.name: chapter5
chapter.element: Gender and age mainstreaming in MdM interventions is much more than gender equity. It means to introduce a gender and age approach that addresses specifically exposures, vulnerabilites, risks, needs, strenghts, weaknesses, opportunities for each group. This provides the proper analysis to tailor specific interventions and methodologies for specific groups. On Health, always Women Health is a priority for MdM much further than Maternal Health, comprehending sexual health and key interventions to fight against VAWG, what is especially crucial during emergencies as well as girls and boys protection. Elders, specially those with special needs (special treatment, reduced mobility) are also object of special attention specially again when they are facing situations as challenging as displacement and migration.

MdM always invests in existing health care actors and infrastructures while addressing health needs in its areas of intervention. Strategic decisions about service provision and needs identification are done in coordination with local actors, being local govermental institutions always strategic partners aiming to strenghten the public health system, as MdM defends worlwide free and universal access to health. Doing so, at the same time, MdM ensures that institutions, as services providers, become accountable in front of rights holders, making also communties aware of their rights and supporting populations in the effective exercise of them.

chapter.name: chapter6
chapter.element:
This MHPSS emergency response in the WB is covering 2 main Geographical areas, Ramallah governorate and East Jerusalem, MDM-F will oversee the direct implementation of the action in Ramallah meanwhile East Jerusalem will be totally covered by The Arab Center for Counselling and Education “ACCE” (Known as the Palestinian Counselling Center “PCC”).  ACCE is a Palestinian mental health non-governmental organization who is present in East jerusalem since 1983 and operational through its coordination base located in Beit Hanina and its Community Mental health center located in the old city of Jerusalem.

The ACCE carries out MHPSS emergency and MHPSS long-term programmatic interventions within the Palestinian community. The ACCE’s main strategies include direct MHPSS Emergency interventions through the provision of MHPSS support visits, psychological First Aid, case management, internal referrals for MHPSS advanced and   therapeutic services to individuals and groups who suffer from psychological problems because of Demolitions and causalities by the occupation. Within this action the ACCE will open its coverage to cover the victims of settlers related traumatic incidents in east Jerusalem with the direct support of MDM. MDM team will refer to PCC all the triggers of demolitions , ISF excessive us of force and settlers violence incidents in east Jerusalem , Moreover MDM will create the linkage and the synergy between ACCE and the ECHO protection consortium in east Jerusalem to enable  protection complementarity between ACCE and the consortium.  

ACCE interventions in east Jerusalem is implemented by a team of trained psychologists and social workers who are authorized to provide this type of services in east Jerusalem taking into consideration the complicated Israeli legislations of providing such type of care in east Jerusalem. The ACCE interventions are provided through the outreach mobile teams who are reaching families and victims in their households, in schools and in Palestinian hospitals operational in east Jerusalem. Due to the lack of MHPSS services providers in east Jerusalem, Advanced MHPSS services including counselling and therapy will be provided by ACCE team. ACCE team with the support of MDM will link the community members in need for basic and protection services with the different protection sources including ECHO consortium, the protection cluster and others. Within this action MDM will reinforce ACCE representation within the relevant cluster groups and sub-working groups such as Projection cluster, MHPSS and Child protection Sub-Working Group and the Settlement Expansion and Practices sub working group.

ACCE works on raising awareness on emergency response by providing the Palestinian communities with information regarding the psychological effects of emergency situations on children and adults, and the methods of dealing with these situations.  This type of awareness raising will be provided through Psychoeducation sessions provided by ACCE staff and trained volunteers. Within this action, ACCE and MDM will further develop this awareness component   through media contributions by radio and television, as well as publications different groups on how to act in times of emergency.

Within its intervention. MDM will work on increasing the awareness of public upon the impact of occupation-related violence on the mental health of population living in West Bank though a study that will focus on the impact on mental health caused by occupation-related violence, ACCE will be MDM partner to carryout and disseminate this study as a main actor covering east jerusalem.

The partnership between ACCE and MDM will be defined in a “Partnership Agreement” that will define the role, tasks and responsibilities of each partner, its financial commitment, communication channels, reporting tools and deadlines. This cooperation will be articulated at different levels, regular coordination meetings at directors level will be carried out by MDM General coordinator and ACCE General director, at operational level MDM Field.co and the Programs director in ACCE will be meeting once a month to follow up on the operational aspects of the project, moreover MDM Field.co will reinforce the linkage between the Protection  consortium and ACCE  , the field.co will work  in ensuring ACCE active participation in the  the Protection cluster and its sub-working groups. ACCE and MDM technical team will carry out monthly technical meetings, MDM MH program manager and ACCE program coordinator will lead these technical meetings that will be focused on unifying the interventions approaches and tools, reporting, follow up of interventions, in addition to technical support. MDM program officer will be in charge of providing the incidents triggers of all type of incidents to ACCE program coordinator who will disseminate it within her team, the program officer will follow the interventions of ACCE in east Jerusalem and will work on reinforcing the linkage between ACCE and the Protection Consortium staff at field level.  In case of massive traumatic incidents, MDM will deploy its MHPSS team to support ACCE in implementing their interventions in east Jerusalem and vice versa ACCE will deploy its team to support MDM MHPSS team in covering massive incidents in Ramallah area. MDM team at coordination, technical and financial levels will ensure regular visits to ACCE teams within then the project.

MDM MEAL officer together with ACCE MEAL officer will cooperate in the creation of the monitoring and evaluation tools of the program, MDM MEAL officer will train ACCE MEAL in the use of MDM electronic Monitoring tool “Monitool “and will ensure her access to the tool for data entry, data analysis and reporting.

MDM administrative and financial will ensure the follow up of PCC in terms of financial expenditures, follow up of financial commitments and financial reporting. MDM logistic team will ensure and train ACCE team in the follow up of ECHO logistic procedures and threshold.

MDM advocacy team will ensure the commitment of ACCE in terms of communication, publication and visibility rules of both MDM and DG ECHO within this action, MDM advocacy team will ensure the review of ACCE communication material content under this project before its publication.  

MDM will be the responsible for the reporting to DG ECHO on all the activities, administration, financial issues as the lead on this project and will guarantee the proper sharing of information, prevent duplication and ensure the right follow up of the project implementation.

grp.element: Arab Center for Counselling and Education (ACCE) or Palestinian Counselling Center (PCC)
7 Al-Sultan Qutuz St., Beit Hanina, East Jerusalem
NNPO

Historical background

The Palestinian Counseling Centre (PCC) is a mental health non-governmental organization established in 1983. The PCC was started by a group of psychologists to respond to the increasing need for mental health services among the Palestinian population. The PCC started intervening at the primary intervention level concentrating its efforts in raising the community’s awareness to the importance of counseling as a form of effective therapy for various psycho-social problems. The PCC then moved to intervene at the secondary level by placing and supervising psychologists, counselors and social workers in schools and primary health clinics. Today, it has become accepted, and even requested, that specialized mental health clinics exist and operate.

The PCC has its headquarters in Beit Hanina - Jerusalem with branch centers /clinics in the old city of Jerusalem, Ramallah, Qalqilya, and Nablus. The PCC employs 45 staff members and serves over 12000 direct beneficiaries.

Areas of intervention

The Palestinian Counseling Center carries out long-term, programmatic interventions within the Palestinian community. The PCC’s main strategies include direct intervention through the provision of therapeutic services to groups who suffer from psychological problems; prevention of developing psychological problems for marginalized groups and groups at risk; capacity building for organizations and individuals specialized in mental health, lobbying and advocacy for improvement of legislation, policies and procedures in mental health and Below, descriptions of the programs that have been implemented over the past 34 years of PCC’s existence are included.

The PCC has a team of trained, multidisciplinary psychologists and psychosocial workers who work to intervene in times of crisis to provide psychological first-aid to victims and raise emergency preparedness in the community. This is done through emergency preparedness and response plans which are prepared on an annual basis to assess the current situation in the country and anticipate possible risks in order to develop the proper response mechanisms.

They will provide provide Psychological First Aid (PFA) to individuals and families impacted by occupation related violence. 

Intervention with Palestinians who have been seriously injured due to Israeli occupation violence including settlers’ violence and use of force by ISF:

Visits to all injured in hospitals to provide psychological first aid (PFA)

Assessment and information gathering

Visits to the injured individuals and their families following their release from the hospital

Development of an intervention plan for working with the injured and their companions / families for a period of two weeks following the incident 

Provision of bags including hygiene kits and essentials to the injured and their accompaniers

Follow-up on the patients referred to relevant appropriate organization to receive specialized services

Intervention with families of palestinian dead because of occupation related violence

Data gathering including names of casualties and family location  

Preliminary visit to families of killed in targeted areas and provision of psycho-social first-aid

Provision of psychological support for families

Visit to families of victims for a period of two weeks

Development of an intervention plan for long-term support for families

Intervention with families whose homes are threatened with demolition or confiscation:

Data and information gathering regarding families facing home demolition orders

Preliminary visit for families threatened with home demolitions 

Define best form of intervention and the provision of information including human rights organizations who can assist with legal and other matters 

Accompaniment of families during demolition and the provision of psycho-social support as required

Follow-up visits following demolition

Awareness raising on the psycho-social impact of traumatic events on individuals and their families - 5 community awareness raising campaigns

Holding awareness raising workshops and meetings with communities at risk of encountering large scale political emergencies. 2 workshops per community = 10 workshops with a total of 300 individuals.

Dissemination of instructions on how to deal with emergency situations.

The partnership between ACCE and MDM will be defined in a “Partnership Agreement” that will define the role, tasks and responsibilities of each partner, its financial commitment, communication channels, reporting tools and deadlines. Reporting by implementing partner will be done on monthly basis and data validated and incorporated to coomon database by MEAL MdM officer.

chapter.name: chapter7
chapter.element:
MDM in Palestine is an active Member in both Health and Nutrition and Protection clusters. MDM is considered as main emergency actor in Gaza for the health and nutrition cluster and In WB for the protection cluster. MDM is attending regularly health and protection cluster meeting in both Gaza and WB. MDM us an important contributor in the identification of the HNO and designing the HRP on yearly bases. Moreover; MDM has been assigned by the health cluster as one of the main emergency responders actors. All MDM project submitted to the HRP 2019 has been approved either under health or protection cluster.

In GAZA; in cooperation with other main actors in the field of emergency (ICRC, MAP, MDM-S, UHWC, PMRS, MSF and UN agencies), MDM is participating in the designing of the both health cluster contingency plan and national emergency mental health plan leaded by WHO and part of MHPSS workgroup. Following the Great March of Return, MDM is also part of the trauma working group, working together with other group members to optimize the resources to the benefit of most needed injuries from the demonstrations. A apart of the coordination with the cluster, MDM is in continuous coordination with the main health actors in Gaza ( MSF , MAP UK, WHO and ICRC) in order to ensure complementarities and  to avoid duplication of work specially at the level of public services.

In  WB: MDM is an active member in both Health Cluster and Protection cluster, MDM is already having validated MHPSS Emergency Response HRP 2019 under the Protection cluster and MH integration in PHCCs HRP 2019 under the Health cluster. Furthermore, MDM is an active member of the MHPSS and Child Protection sub-working group at central level and its related MHPSS operational working groups at Governorates level. MDM is an active member within the Settlements Expansion and Practices “sub- working group and is considered as its reference for MHPSS impacts, MDM coordinates its advocacy initiatives with this group in addition to other forms as AIDA Advocacy working group.

MDM will keep a close coordination with the ECHO Protection Consortium actors considering MDM MHPSS Emergency Response as a complementary intervention to the consortium interventions, the coordination will be at various levels including triggers, responses, protection referrals, advocacy initiatives, joint analysis and identification of trends, in addition to common operational assessments in case of massive incidents. The cooperation and coordination with the consortium partners was concentrated around the NWB, by extending the area of coverage of MDM to Ramallah and east Jerusalem, MDM will replicate, reinforce, and continue the relationship with the Consortium partners’ focal points in the 2 new targeted governorates. MDM will reinforce ACCE – Arab Counselling Center for Education – to adopt the same cooperation and coordination approach with consortium there.

MdM is in continuous coordination with local and international MHPSS service providers (ACCE, MSF-F, YMCA and the Ministry of Health Community Mental Health Centres) as a main target of referrals of victims in need for advanced MHPSS services, using the National Mental Health Referral System which was launched by MOH and MDM in December 2015.

MDM has more than 10 years’ experience working in Palestine through its main operational offices in Gaza and WB. MDM In Gaza is working in public health sector in direct link with different departments at the MOH. MDM in Gaza has achieved to establish and maintain strong and trustable partnership with the MOH and other related authorities. MDM is highly respected by the decision makers at the MOH for its commitment and efficiency working hard to fill the gaps and to meet the needs of the population. MDM is working hand to hand with the MOH in all project cycles; the International Cooperation Department is concerned in sitting the general objectives of intervention at local level and responsible for the administrative general approval of MDM field interventions. The Primary health directorate and Hospital Administration agreed on all the technical methodologies of the intervention and on facilitating the access to the health structures in the field and Central stores: is the department involved in identifying the needs and approval of qualities and quantities of supplies provided to the MoH. In WB; working in MHPSS, MDM has developed very close and trustful coordination with the Ministry of Health at central level in Ramallah and governorates offices. MDM has established and maintains positive and repeated contacts with the Palestinian health authorities as the interventions aim at improving the quantity and quality of MHPSS services. MDM is an active member of the MOH MHPSS Thematic Group who is working on the development of the MHPSS Emergency Preparedness plan with WHO. MOH Community Mental Health Centres are one of the main referral sources for MHPSS Advanced services. The same with the Ministry of Education through the counselling department responsible of the MHPSS services in the MoE schools. MdM is working with the MoE counselling department since 2008 in a series of programs building their capacity and responding to the MHPSS in the schools.

MDM is a Humanitarian and Development actor implementing both interventions in Palestine as many other actors working in the area. In Gaza; within the context of protracted humanitarian crises it is difficult to separate between the two types of interventions. As was mentioned in previous sessions, MDM in Gaza has been working on strengthen the emergency preparedness at different levels from institutional to community level and being acting as immediate responder during and post crises. At the same time, MDM cooperates too, with a local partner, work committee (UAWC). During the last year MDM worked with UAWC to integrate the BLS practices within the day to day activity conducted by their target (Farmers and fishermen). Culture and Free Thought Association (CFTA). MdM has supported the structuring of the Mental Health Department of CFTA contributing to a better provision of MHPSS services in three centers of the organization in khan Younis and the Middle Area and has developed a project about Family Planning in the Women Center of CFTA in Al Bureij.

In WB; The emergency protection intervention is in line with MOH MHPSS long-term strategy 2015-2019 where response to Trauma is one of the main priorities. Within its strategy MDM will work on the communing 3 years in reinforcing the MHPSS capacities of MOH Primary Health Care Centres to provide MHPSS support to emergency and common metal health cases.  MDM and ACCE are working in building the capacities of 5 MOE Psychosocial Support Teams in the NWB with the objective of reinforcing the capacities of the MOE teams to provide proper MHPSS emergency response following traumatic incidents in their schools.  In 2018, MDM and ACCE worked on the development of the technical and operational guidelines of the MOE teams, supervised the members of the teams and their supervisors and accompanied them while providing MHPSS in their schools.

chapter.name: chapter8
chapter.element:
Considered as a priority, monitoring, survey and evaluation process will involve MDM at the different levels of the organization: Field, Mission Coordination, and HQ. This involvement is facilitated by the existence of an MDM on-line monitoring tool “MONITOOL” common to all MDM missions, and a communication and reporting system among the different organizational levels.

At the field level, the existing data collection system that feeds the MONITOOL will be updated in order to include the needed data to follow the activities, results and associated indicators of the present proposal. This system constitutes the basic tool for the monitoring and survey of MDM activities, and involves the whole team of MDM. Field coordinators together with the Medical Coordinator supervise and analyze the data and the reports in monthly bases in order to monitor the project and re-adapt strategies and activities when needed. These reports are shared with the rest of the coordination in Jerusalem as well as with HQ.

The General coordinator, based in Jerusalem, ensures that the MDM projects are undertaken according to national policy, as well as MDM own country strategy. Internal weekly and monthly coordination meetings are held, in order to not only coordinate activities but also to facilitate monitoring of implementation.

The mission, counts with the technical support provided by the Desk Medical Adviser and the Health and Advocacy Direction at the HQ level through regular exchanges.
